The Denver Broncos’ consumption of 700 Uncrustables per week is an unusual observation that stands out prominently in the graph, far exceeding the other teams’ averages. This disparity emphasizes how outliers can distort interpretations of trends. Additionally, the lack of a clear correlation between Uncrustables consumption and NFL standings is striking, as there is no consistent positive or negative pattern.

The graph raises questions such as: Why do the Broncos consume so many Uncrustables compared to other teams? Is there a cultural or logistical reason behind this high number? Additionally, are there any other variables, like team size or dietary preferences, that might explain the data variations?

This graph is relatable in terms of how nutrition and convenience foods impact performance in professional or personal settings. In my community, convenience snacks like Uncrustables are popular among busy students or athletes who need quick, easy energy sources during long days or competitions.

I notice that Denver seems to eat a much higher amount of uncrustables than every other NFL team, including their closest neighboring teams - geography wise.  I also notice that a lot of the teams that do eat the most uncrustables every week (excluding Denver) are mostly coastal cities, like Seattle, Charlotte, Miami, and NY.

What I wonder is if higher elevation has something to do with the intake of sweeter foods.  While the big coastal cities may intake a lot of uncrustables by the week, they are exactly that, coastal cities.  Denver, on the other hand, holds a massive height above sea level, an incredibly different environment from many other cities on the list.  Many sweet foods take time to prepare and serve, unlike uncrustables, which a team could grab in between practices with ease.  I also wonder if Denver gets its uncrustables directly from the source.  I googled where the main manufacturers of uncrustables are located, and one of the two main manufacturers is located only 38 miles away from where the Broncos practice and play.

There doesn’t appear to be any noticeable connection between Uncrustable consumption and win-loss-tie percentages.

We are curious why the Denver team eats so many Uncrustables. What makes Uncrustables their choice? Which player position has the highest relative consumption of Uncrustables? Why have the players stopped eating oranges? What is the most popular Uncrustable flavor?

This is relevant to us since our school cafeteria also sells Uncrustables, and many of us include them in our lunches. Additionally, the Uncrustable Company could leverage this information for advertising and product promotion.

Our eye-catching title is PB&J Playbook: Exploring the NFL's Fascination with Uncrustables.

original_comments.name: Moderator Sharon
original_comments.comment info:
Many of you are using the word "correlation" to describe the relationship between the number of Uncrustables eaten by a team  and their NFL standing.  

In statistics, the word "correlation" is reserved for a relationship that is linear. You can see if a relationship is linear when you plot the two variables for each team on a scatter plot (one variable for each axis).  We have plotted the team’s variables in the scatter plot below the featured graph.  Do the points increase or decrease, more or less, in a line?  If not, we can only say that there is an association, if there is a relationship or pattern to the points, or there is no association, if the points are scattered.

For the scatter plot in this release, is there an association between number of Uncrustables eaten by a team and their NFL standing?

original_comments.name: Lily AOSE
original_comments.comment info:
I notice that while the Denver Broncos consume the most Uncrustables—700 per week—their win percentage doesn’t seem to correlate with this high snack intake. In fact, teams with win rates above 70% typically eat fewer than 200 Uncrustables per week, showing little connection between snack consumption and performance. Many lower-performing teams (with win rates under 40%) also consume fewer Uncrustables, with Denver being the main outlier. This suggests that Uncrustables may be more tied to team culture or logistics rather than directly influencing a team’s success. I wonder why these teams prefer Uncrustables, and what led to the shift from the traditional halftime snack of oranges to something like Uncrustables.
